articles.headline: Russia and U.S. Report Breakthrough on Arms
articles.snippet: The two countries expect to sign a new treaty next month that would slash nuclear arsenals, officials from both nations said Wednesday.
articles.abstract: The two countries expect to sign a new treaty next month that would slash nuclear arsenals, officials from both nations said Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Russia have broken a logjam in arms control negotiations and expect to sign a treaty next month to slash their nuclear arsenals to the lowest levels in half a century, officials in both nations said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Behind Consumer Agency Idea, a Tireless Advocate
articles.snippet: If there’s one thing the financial industry dislikes more than a consumer protection agency, it’s the thought that Elizabeth Warren might lead it.
articles.abstract: If there’s one thing the financial industry dislikes more than a consumer protection agency, it’s the thought that Elizabeth Warren might lead it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ask Elizabeth Warren, scourge of Wall Street bankers, how they treat consumers, and she will shake her head with indignation. She will talk about morality, about fairness, about what she calls their “let them eat cake” attitude toward taxpayers. If she is riled enough, she might even spit out the Warren version of an expletive.

articles.headline: IPhone App to Sidestep AT&T
articles.snippet: Line2 takes a big step toward a future when cellphone users won’t need to rely on a cellphone carrier’s service.
articles.abstract: Line2 takes a big step toward a future when cellphone users won’t need to rely on a cellphone carrier’s service.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a little $1 iPhone app, Line2 sure has the potential to shake up an entire industry.

articles.headline: Bank of America to Reduce Mortgage Balances
articles.snippet: Bank of America said that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt of borrowers who could lose their homes.
articles.abstract: Bank of America said that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt of borrowers who could lose their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America said on Wednesday that it would begin forgiving some mortgage debt in an effort to keep distressed borrowers from losing their homes.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Louise Story

articles.headline: Catholic Charity and Sprint Tangle Over Texting
articles.snippet: A Catholic charity is still seeking answers after Sprint discontinued a fund-raising effort by text for Haiti.
articles.abstract: A Catholic charity is still seeking answers after Sprint discontinued a fund-raising effort by text for Haiti.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the earthquake devastated Haiti, Catholic Relief Services tried to gather contributions for its efforts using the hottest trend in giving: donations via cellphone.

articles.headline: Ding! Mail. OMG! It’s Steve Jobs.
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs, the secretive head of Apple, has been busy sending replies to e-mail messages from customers.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs, the secretive head of Apple, has been busy sending replies to e-mail messages from customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jezper Söderlund, a music producer in Gothenburg, Sweden, was thrilled to receive a one-word e-mail message earlier this month.

articles.headline: Vatican Declined to Defrock U.S. Priest Who Abused Boys
articles.snippet: Vatican officials, including the future Pope Benedict XVI, did not defrock a priest who molested as many as 200 deaf boys, even after warnings from several bishops, church files show.
articles.abstract: Vatican officials, including the future Pope Benedict XVI, did not defrock a priest who molested as many as 200 deaf boys, even after warnings from several bishops, church files show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top Vatican officials — including the future Pope Benedict XVI — did not defrock a priest who molested as many as 200 deaf boys, even though several American bishops repeatedly warned them that failure to act on the matter could embarrass the church, according to church files newly unearthed as part of a lawsuit.

articles.headline: Britons Cling to Services, Despite Debt
articles.snippet: Government outlays eat up half the nation’s economic output, but voters are having second thoughts about the Tories’ call to shrink the budget.
articles.abstract: Government outlays eat up half the nation’s economic output, but voters are having second thoughts about the Tories’ call to shrink the budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain operates one of the largest welfare states in Europe. And that, it seems, is just fine with many of the British.

articles.headline: Mobs Are Born as Word Grows by Text Message
articles.snippet: So-called flash mobs of teenagers take to  the streets of Philadelphia, sometimes brawling and vandalizing.
articles.abstract: So-called flash mobs of teenagers take to  the streets of Philadelphia, sometimes brawling and vandalizing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It started innocently enough seven years ago as an act of performance art where people linked through social-networking Web sites and text messaging suddenly gathered on the streets for impromptu pillow fights in New York, group disco routines in London, and even a huge snowball fight in Washington.

articles.headline: Start Saving Early, and Keep an Eye on Shifting Needs
articles.snippet: To prepare for retirement, financial advisers suggest, formulate a saving plan early — and then be prepared to adjust it.
articles.abstract: To prepare for retirement, financial advisers suggest, formulate a saving plan early — and then be prepared to adjust it.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN economic oracles would have trouble predicting their retirement needs with a high degree of precision.

articles.headline: Social Security to See Payout Exceed Pay-In This Year
articles.snippet: The system is projected to pay out more in benefits this year than it receives in taxes, a tipping point toward insolvency that was not expected before 2016.
articles.abstract: The system is projected to pay out more in benefits this year than it receives in taxes, a tipping point toward insolvency that was not expected before 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bursting of the real estate bubble and the ensuing recession have hurt jobs, home prices and now Social Security.

articles.headline: The Importance of Being Counted (Pop. 842)
articles.snippet: City officials in San Antonio, Fla., are determined not to let residents be undercounted in the census again.
articles.abstract: City officials in San Antonio, Fla., are determined not to let residents be undercounted in the census again.

articles.headline: Unions Make Strides as They Attack Banks
articles.snippet: Labor groups have a complicated relationship with Wall Street: they capitalize on populist anger against banks, and yet the unions represent a huge bloc of shareholders.
articles.abstract: Labor groups have a complicated relationship with Wall Street: they capitalize on populist anger against banks, and yet the unions represent a huge bloc of shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the city of Los Angeles started looking into its complex financial contracts with banks earlier this year, some council members turned to an unusual corner for financial advice: labor unions.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Louise Story

articles.headline: Take a Few Hours and Unlock Some Cash
articles.snippet: Keeping a financial to-do list and tackling it once a year can put significant money back in your wallet.
articles.abstract: Keeping a financial to-do list and tackling it once a year can put significant money back in your wallet.
articles.lead_paragraph: To be a modern American consumer is to be plagued by a never-ending, guilt-inducing stream of undone tasks.

articles.headline: Bernanke Hints at Timing of Exit Strategy
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chairman hinted the central bank might sell part of its large portfolio of mortgage-backed securities when the time comes to start tightening credit.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman hinted the central bank might sell part of its large portfolio of mortgage-backed securities when the time comes to start tightening credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, hinted on Thursday that the central bank might be open to selling part of its huge portfolio of mortgage-backed securities when the time came to start tightening credit.
